heading.title: Supreme Court
SUPREME COURT ACT 1970
PART 5 POWERS [ss 65–76C]
DIVISION 1 POWERS GENERALLY [ss 65–76C] 2 of 2

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCA s 74] s 74 Discharge of lien or security

p.text: Where, in any proceedings—
a party claims the recovery of specific property other than land, and

the party from whom recovery is sought claims to be entitled to retain the property by virtue of a lien or otherwise as security for money but does not otherwise dispute the title of the party claiming the recovery,
the Court may order—

that the party claiming the recovery be at liberty to pay into Court, to abide the event of the proceedings, the amount of money in respect of which the lien or other security is claimed and such further sum, if any, for interest and costs as the Court may direct; and
that, upon payment into Court, such judgment be given for recovery of the property as the nature of the case may require.
[s 74 am Act 226 of 1989 s 3 and Sch]

heading.title: NOTES

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 74.5] Claims to recover specific property

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 74.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 93(1)(a), s 93(1)(c).
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 25.4.

heading.title: Claims to recover specific property

p.text: This section applies to proceedings for the recovery of specific property. These include claims for the delivery of goods under s 93(1)(a) of the CPA and also claims for delivery of the goods or payment of their assessed value under s 93(1)(c) of the CPA. It also applies to proceedings by an administrator for the return of title deeds. This section provides an additional means by which a plaintiff can recover property that is subject to a lien. The alternative means include orders under r 25.4 (which includes provision for the disposal of perishable property). In addition, the court in its equitable jurisdiction may order the delivery up, upon terms, of chattels which are of particular value or importance to a plaintiff eg where they are needed in the carrying on of the plaintiff's business: Doulton Potteries Ltd v Bronotte [1971] 1 NSWLR 591 . Although, as Hope J remarked in that case, there was no similar power at common law, the present section remedies that omission. Indeed, it would appear that the discretion conferred upon the court by this section is somewhat wider than the equitable remedy in that it is not limited to any particular type of property.

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 74.10] Solicitor's lien

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 74.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Legal Profession Act 2004 s 728.

heading.title: Solicitor's lien

p.text: This section and s 728 of the Legal Profession Act 2004 permit the court to order the delivery of property that is the subject of a solicitor's lien: Re Galland (1885) 31 Ch D 296 : In addition, the court may exercise its jurisdiction to grant relief in equity against the exercise of the lien: Ismail v Richards Butler [1996] 2 All ER 506; [1996] 3 WLR 711 . Usually orders for delivery will not be made except on the basis of either a payment into court of the amount claimed by the solicitor, or an undertaking by the client's new solicitor to preserve the former solicitor's lien: Gamlen Chemical Co (UK) Ltd v Rochem Ltd [1980] 1 WLR 614 ; Jankowski v Mastoris (1995) 7 BPR 14,589 .

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 74.15] Payment into court

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 74.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 94.

heading.title: Payment into court

p.text: The whole amount claimed by the person claiming the lien must usually be paid into court, notwithstanding it exceeds the value of the specific property: Gebruder Naf v Ploton (1890) 15 QBD 13; Beneficial Finance Corp Ltd v Conway (No 2) [1971] VR 594 at 607 . Generally interest and costs should be included in the amount paid into court. Interest should be assessed on the same principles as under s 94 of the Act. Interest should be allowed for the period from when the amount in question first became due until the date judgment could reasonably be anticipated in the proceedings: Harry v Rottnest Sightseeing Cruises Pty Ltd [1988] WAR 239 . The court has no discretion under the present section to require payment into court of less than the amount of the defendant's claim. In an appropriate case the court may accept an undertaking as to payment: see [SCA s 74.10] .

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 74.20] No determination of the merits of the lien claimed

heading.title: No determination of the merits of the lien claimed

p.text: Where an application is made under this section the court will not investigate the merits of the defendant's claim, either as to amount or entitlement, so long as the claim is made bona fide: Gebruder Naf v Ploton (1890) 15 QBD 13; Segbedzi v Glah [1989] 139 NLJ 1303. Accordingly, if the real issue that the plaintiff wishes to raise involves a challenge to the validity of the defendant's lien, an application under this section is not appropriate.
Legislation cited in [SCA s 74.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 74.

Where an application is made under s 74 the court does not have jurisdiction to assess the value of the goods, or investigate the merits of the defendant's claim, so long as the defendant's claim is bona fide: Gebruder Naf v Ploton (1890) 15 QBD 13; Segbedzi v Glah [1989] 139 NLJ 1303.

No proceedings shall be open to objection on the ground that a merely declaratory judgment or order is sought thereby and the Court may make binding declarations of right whether any consequential relief is or could be claimed or not.

ci:cite.ci:content: Act 24 of 1901 s 10; RSC (Rev) 1965 O 15 r 16.

heading.title: NOTES

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 75.10] Scope of the jurisdiction to grant declaratory relief

heading.title: Scope of the jurisdiction to grant declaratory relief

p.text: As a superior court, the Supreme Court has inherent power to grant declaratory relief: Ainsworth v Criminal Justice Commission (1992) 175 CLR 564 at 581; 106 ALR 11 at 22 ; Telstra Corp Ltd v AAPT Pty Ltd [1999] NSWSC 853; BC9905407 . A claim for a declaration need not be based on an ordinary cause of action nor confined to consequential relief of a kind that would be available in respect of such a cause of action: Guaranty Trust Co of New York v Hannay and Co [1915] 2 KB 536. The declaratory power therefore provides a useful remedy that can be employed in a great variety of situations. Indeed it has been said that the scope of the power is unlimited, except by the court's own discretion: Hanson v Radcliffe Urban District Council [1922] 2 Ch 490; [1922] All ER Rep 160 ; Ibeneweka v Egbuna [1964] 1 WLR 219; Sutherland Shire Council v Leyendekkers (1970) 91 WN (NSW) 250 ; Forster v Jododex Australia Pty Ltd (1972) 127 CLR 421; [1972] ALR 1303 ; Johnco Nominees Pty Ltd v Albury-Wodonga (NSW) Corp [1977] 1 NSWLR 43.
Examples of the use of the remedy include:

heading.title: Interpretation of court orders:

p.text: Cawood v Green (NSWCA, 26 June 1993, unreported) (declaration as to the meaning of a court order for the purpose of avoiding unintentional contempt); Blanch (t/as Hicksons) v British American Tobacco Australia Services Ltd (2005) 62 NSWLR 653; [2005] NSWSC 241; BC200501638 (declaration sought for the purpose of avoiding unintentional contempt of order); see also [36.16.72] .

heading.title: Determination of the powers of inferior courts, tribunals or statutory decision makers:

p.text: Bacon v Rose [1972] 2 NSWLR 793 (alleged unauthorised committal proceedings); Donges v Ratcliffe [1975] 1 NSWLR 501 ( licensing magistrates obligation to give reasons for their decisions); Maksimovic v Walsh [1983] 2 NSWLR 656 (coroner ought not suggest a named persons have committed an indictable offence); Commonwealth Bank of Australia v Hattersley (2001) 51 NSWLR 333; [2001] NSWSC 60; BC200100604 (costs assessor not entitled to make an interlocutory direction).

heading.title: Determination of the powers of domestic tribunals and associations:

p.text: McClelland v Burning Palms Surf Lifesaving Club (2002) 191 ALR 759; [2002] NSWSC 470; BC200203189 at [110]–[117] ; Forbes v NSW Trotting Club Ltd (1979) 143 CLR 242; 25 ALR 1; BC7900060 ; Harrison v Hearn [1972] 1 NSWLR 428 ; Field v NSW Greyhound Breeders, Owners & Trainers Association Ltd [1972] 2 NSWLR 948 ; Rose v Boxing NSW Inc [2007] NSWSC 20; BC200700280 at [55] [59] (expulsion of boxing referee from association — damages in addition to declaration); Plenty v Seventh Day Adventist Church of Port Pirie (1986) 43 SASR 121 .

heading.title: Determination of the scope and content of statutory obligations:

p.text: Declarations may be sought and made as to the existence of an obligation to comply with statutory requirements: Simmonds v Newport Abercarn Black Vein Steam Coal Co Ltd [1921] 1 KB 616 ; Dyson v A-G [1911] 1 KB 410; [1912] 1 Ch 158 ; Nicholls v Tavistock Urban District Council [1923] 2 Ch 18 ; Grant v Knaresborough Urban District Council [1928] Ch 310. Similarly, proceedings may be commenced for orders restraining conduct alleged to be contrary to some legislative provision, particularly local government or planning legislation: Attorney-General v Ashborne Recreation Ground Co [1903] 1 Ch 101 ; Cooney v Ku-ring-gai Municipal Council (1963) 114 CLR 582; [1964] ALR 98; BC6300660 ; Attorney-General (NSW); Ex rel Corporate Affairs Commission v Australian Softwood Forests Pty Ltd [1979] 2 NSWLR 73; (1979) 4 ACLR 254 ; Australian Softwood Forests Pty Ltd v A-G (NSW); Ex rel Corporate Affairs Commission (1981) 148 CLR 121; 36 ALR 257; BC8100099 ; Duchess of Argyll v Duke of Argyll [1967] Ch 302; [1965] 1 All ER 611 ; Duff v McCulloch (1985) 11 FCR 237; 65 ALR 677 . The most common example of this is to be found in proceedings concerning the construction of provisions of the companies and securities legislation: Attorney-General (NSW) v Australian Fixed Trusts Ltd [1974] 1 NSWLR 110; (1974) 5 ACLR 423 ; Mutual Home Loan Funds of Australia Ltd v A-G (NSW) (1973) 130 CLR 103; 2 ALR 241; BC7300053 ; McColl v Ryan [1968] 3 NSWR 342; (1968) 89 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 74 .

heading.title: Determination of other rights and obligations:

p.text: Cheetham v McGeechan [1971] 2 NSWLR 222 (when a prisoner should be released); Construction Industry Training Board v A-G [1973] Ch 173 (whether plaintiff should be registered as a charity); Oil Basins Ltd v Commonwealth (1993) 178 CLR 643; 117 ALR 338; [1993] HCA 60; BC9303591 (declaration as to taxation liability); Ampolex Ltd v Perpetual Trustee Co (Canberra) Ltd (1995) 37 NSWLR 405; BC9505356 (declaration as to whether a solicitor was bound to produce documents that were the subject of a notice issued by the ASC).

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 75.15] Discretionary refusal to make declarations

heading.title: Discretionary refusal to make declarations

p.text: Although declarations can be made in a wide variety of cases, an applicant for a declaration must discharge their onus of proof in relation to both matters of fact and law: Blanch (t/as Hicksons) v British American Tobacco Australia Services Ltd (2005) 62 NSWLR 653; [2005] NSWSC 241; BC200501638 . But even where that onus has been discharged the court will not grant a declaration unless satisfied both that the declaration sought is appropriate and that it has sufficient practical utility in resolving a dispute: Neeta (Epping) Pty Ltd v Phillips (1974) 131 CLR 286; 3 ALR 151; BC7400026 . The requirement relating to the appropriateness of the declaration relates both to matters of form: see [SCA s 75.25] ; and subject matter: see [SCA s 75.20]. The requirement for practical utility translates into a number of more specific restrictions on the exercise of the declaratory power. A declaration will not usually be granted in respect of a hypothetical or merely academic question: Bruce v Commonwealth Trade Marks Label Assn (1907) 4 CLR 1569; 13 ALR 582; [1907] HCA 41; BC0700035 . Such a question arises where the applicant has no real substantive interest in the matter to be decided: Johnco Nominees Pty Ltd v Albury-Wodonga (NSW) Corp [1977] 1 NSWLR 43 (interpretation of a government planning policy statement). A declaration may be refused where no relevant substantive remedies are claimed: see [SCA s 63.10] ; or where no declaration could be drawn that would deal satisfactorily with all of the contingencies affecting the circumstances between the parties: Challenge Bank Ltd v Mailman [1993] NSWJB 53 .

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 75.20] Declarations relating to other current judicial proceedings

heading.title: Declarations relating to other current judicial proceedings

p.text: Where proceedings are pending before another court the Supreme Court will only exercise its declaratory powers in exceptional circumstances. There is a similar reluctance where the declaration sought would interfere with the conduct or report of a special commission of enquiry: Jackson v Slattery [1984] 1 NSWLR 599 . This reluctance is especially the case where the matter involves a determination for which there are exclusive procedures for review and appeal of the other proceedings: Currabubula Holdings Pty Ltd v State Bank of New South Wales [2000] NSWSC 232; BC200001561 (exclusive provisions for review of a costs assessment): see also [SCA s 69.45] ; Calvin v Carr [1979] 1 NSWLR 1; [1980] AC 574 ; Hill v Green (1999) 48 NSWLR 161; 96 IR 371; [1999] NSWCA 477; BC9908532 at [154] –[164] . There is also a demonstrable reluctance to grant declarations in relation to inferior courts conducting criminal or committal proceedings: Connor v Sankey [1976] 2 NSWLR 570; (1976) 21 ALR 317 ; BC7800068 ; Csidei v Anderson [1977] 1 NSWLR 747 at 752–3; (1977) 3 ACLR 138 ; Sankey v Whitlam (1978) 142 CLR 1; 21 ALR 505; BC7800068 ; Green v Jones [1979] 2 NSWLR 812 at 818; (1979) 39 FLR 428 and Perry v Nash (1980) 32 ALR 177; 47 FLR 210 ; see also [SCA s 69.20] .

There is a clear judicial reluctance to entertain civil proceedings claiming declarations where the issue involved properly falls for determination in criminal proceedings: Imperial Tobacco Ltd v A-G [1981] AC 718; [1980] 1 All ER 866 ; Attorney-General v Abel [1984] 1 QB 795; Nicholls v Queensland [1983] 1 Qd R 580 (alleged misconduct in relation to the keeping of the jury during a criminal trial); Coles v Wood [1981] 1 NSWLR 723 (validity of search warrant). As a general rule, the court ought not to make declarations as to the commission of a criminal offence: Pedler v BFC Finance Ltd (NSWSC, Mahoney J, 28 December 1972, unreported); Kintominas v A-G (NSW) (NSWCA, 9 December 1985, unreported); cf Shore Disposal Ltd v ED DeWolfe Trucking Ltd (1977) 72 DLR (3d) 219. However, the refusal to make declarations in such cases is a matter of discretion rather than a lack of power: Sankey v Whitlam (1978) 142 CLR 1; 21 ALR 505; BC7800068 ; Grand Junction Waterworks Co v Hampton Urban District Council [1898] 2 Ch 331 at 338–344; [1895-9] All ER Rep 480 ; Smeeton v A-G [1920] 1 Ch 86 . Consequently, the mere fact that the substantial issue to be decided in the declaratory proceedings might also fall for determination in criminal proceedings does not necessarily bar the granting of declaratory relief. An example of such a declaration being made is to be found in Shapowloff v Dunn [1973] 2 NSWLR 468; (1974) CLC ¶40-135 .

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 75.25] Form and effect of declaration

heading.title: Form and effect of declaration

p.text: A summons should specifically state the declaration being sought: Biss v Smallburgh Rural District Council [1965] Ch 335 . The declaration will only bind parties to the proceedings: Australian Oil Exploration Ltd v Lachberg (1958) 101 CLR 119 at 133–4; [1959] ALR 65; BC5800300 . With every declaratory order there is impliedly liberty to apply reserved so that the court can make any appropriate consequential order that may be required: Royal Insurance Co Ltd v Mylius (1926) 38 CLR 477 at 497; [1927] VLR 1; BC2600007 , per Isaacs J, following the Privy Council in Fischer v Secretary of State for India (1898) LR 26 Ind App 16 at 29.
Subject to subsections (2) and (3) , this section applies to an appeal to the Court and to an appeal in proceedings in the Court.
This section does not apply to so much of an appeal as relates to a claim in the appeal—
for a new trial on a cause of action for debt, damages or other money or for possession of land, or for detention of goods; or
for the setting aside of a verdict, finding, assessment or judgment on a cause of action of any of those kinds,
being an appeal arising out of—
a trial with a jury in the Court; or
a trial—
with or without a jury in an action commenced before the commencement of section 4 of the District Court (Amendment) Act 1975; or
with a jury in an action commenced after the commencement of that section,
in the District Court.
in the District Court.
[subs (2) am Act 1 of 1975 s 4]
This section does not apply to:
an appeal to the Court under the Crimes (Local Courts Appeal and Review) Act 2001 , or
to a case stated under the Criminal Appeal Act 1912 .
[subs (3) subst Act 121 of 2001 s 4 and Sch 2, effective 7 July 2003]
This section has effect subject to any Act.
Where the decision or other matter under appeal has been given after a hearing, the appeal shall be by way of rehearing.
The Court shall have the powers and duties of the court, body or other person from whom the appeal is brought, including powers and duties concerning—
amendment;
the drawing of inferences and the making of findings of fact; and
the assessment of damages and other money sums.
The Court may receive further evidence.
Notwithstanding subsection (7) , where the appeal is from a judgment after a trial or hearing on the merits, the Court shall not receive further evidence except on special grounds.
Subsection (8) does not apply to evidence concerning matters occurring after the trial or hearing.
The Court may make any finding or assessment, give any judgment, make any order or give any direction which ought to have been given or made or which the nature of the case requires.
[subs (10) subst Act 226 of 1989 s 3 and Sch 1]
[s 75A insrt Act 41 of 1972 s 7]

heading.title: NOTES

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 75A.5] Scope of the section

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 75A.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 SCA s 101(1), SCA s 102, SCA ss 106–107, SCA ss 118(3), 121(3), SCA s 48, SCA s 75A(2)(c), SCA s 75A(4).
(NSW) Supreme Court Rules 1970 SCR Pt 60 r 17.

heading.title: Scope of the section

p.text: The section applies to appeals from a division of the court to the Court of Appeal (the jurisdiction is conferred by SCA s 101(1) ) and to appeals from an associate judge to a judge (see UCPR r 49.4 and SCR Pt 60 r 17 ).It also applies (subject to SCA s 75A(4) and the considerations discussed in [SCA s 75A.12] ) to appeals to the court from other bodies, eg, the specified tribunals referred to in SCA s 48 .

The section does not apply to appeals arising out of a trial with a jury: SCA s 75A(2)(c) . Proceedings to challenge or set aside a jury verdict (or a judgment after a verdict) lie by way of appeal to the Court of Appeal under SCA s 102 . In such an appeal, the court may exercise the powers conferred by SCA ss 106–107 : see also UCPR r 51.53 .

The present section does not apply to proceedings that are not appeals, eg, proceedings under SCA ss 118(3) and 121(3) to set aside or vary a judgment or order of an associate judge or other officer of the court.

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 75A.10] Appeal by way of rehearing

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 75A.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 75A(4), s 75A(7).

heading.title: Appeal by way of rehearing

p.text: The appeals to which the present section applies are by way of rehearing – subject to any contrary provision in the legislation conferring the right of appeal: see s 75A(4) and (5). The term “rehearing” has a degree of ambiguity. Its actual significance depends on the particular legislative scheme: see further the discussion in [50.16.5] . However, the basic appeal function, as distinct from the material that may be taken into account and the orders that can properly be made, is unaffected by the mere characterisation of an appeal as a “rehearing”: Da Costa v Cockburn Salvage & Trading Pty Ltd (1970) 124 CLR 192 at 208; [1971] ALR 97; BC7000020 . (The basic appeal function is discussed further in [SCA s 75A.12] ).

heading.title: Rehearing procedure

p.text: A rehearing is not a retrial. The appellant carries the onus of showing that the decision appealed from ought to be reversed: Powell v Streatham Manor Nursing Home [1935] AC 243 at 249, 263; [1935] All ER Rep 58 : see also [SCA s 75A.15]–[SCA s 75A.40] . Witnesses are not recalled: Da Costa v Cockburn Salvage & Trading Pty Ltd , above, CLR at 208–9; Quilter v Mapleson (1882) 9 QBD 672 at 676 . Subject to the exercise of the statutory power to receive further evidence (SCA s 75A(7) , (8) and (9)), the appeal by way of rehearing is conducted on the transcript of the evidence taken at the trial. Neither party can rely on matters that were not raised at the trial (at least where the failure to raise the point may have affected the course of the trial): Chilcotin Pty Ltd v Cenelage Pty Ltd [1999] NSWCA 11; BC9901346 at [12]–[18] ; see also [51.53.105]–[51.52.130] .

heading.title: Essential distinctions between appeal and appeal by way of rehearing

p.text: There are three distinctions between an appeal, in the strict sense, and an appeal by way of rehearing. First a “rehearing” power is likely to be accompanied by an additional power, even if it is limited, to receive further evidence. A mere power to determine appeals does not permit the reception of further evidence: Mickelberg v R (1989) 167 CLR 259 at 266-71; 86 ALR 321 [1989] HCA 35 .

Second, a provision for “rehearing” is likely to be supplemented by a specific power to give any judgment or assessment the nature of the case requires. (Both of these features are present in SCA s 75A(7)–(10) .)

Third, and perhaps most fundamentally, in an appeal, in the strict sense, the appeal court can only determine whether the original judgment was correct at that time it was given: Allesch v Maunz (2000) 203 CLR 172; 173 ALR 648; [2000] HCA 40; BC200004312 at [23] ; Victorian Stevedoring and General Contracting Co Pty Ltd v Dignan (1931) 46 CLR 73 at 109; [1932] ALR 22; BC3200041 ; Ponnamma v Arumogam [1905] AC 383 . Where the appeal is by way of rehearing, the court must determine the appeal according to the law that applies when the appeal is heard: Attorney-General v Birmingham Tame and Rea District Drainage Board [1912] AC 788 at 801 ; Attorney-General v Vernazza [1960] 3 All ER 97; [1960] AC 965 ; Quilter v Mapleson (1882) 9 QBD 672 at 676 ; Marsland v Andjelic (1993) 31 NSWLR 162; (1993) Aust Torts Reports ¶81-249; BC9303924 (increase in the statutory limit on a component of damages): see further [SCA s 75A.56] . The potential significance of the distinction between the two types of appeal is neatly illustrated by the High Court's decision in Victorian Stevedoring and General Contracting Co Pty Ltd v Dignan (1931) 46 CLR 73; [1932] ALR 22; BC3200041 (where penal regulations had been disallowed since the appellant’s conviction).

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 75A.12] Appeal — basic character

heading.title: Appeal — basic character

p.text: The basic appeal function involves a fundamental principle, and a related qualification. The fundamental principle, recognised as inherent in the appeal concept, is that an appeal court must determine whether the appealed decision was correct (ie, neither the result of “some legal, factual or discretionary error”: Allesch v Maunz (2000) 203 CLR 172; 173 ALR 648; [2000] HCA 40; BC200004312 at [23] ; nor attended by significant procedural error: see eg [51.53.50] (failure to provide natural justice), [51.53.55] (bias)) and not simply assess whether the decision was reasonably open: CSR Ltd v Della Maddalena (2006) 224 ALR 1; [2006] HCA 1; BC200600188 at [16] ; Fox v Percy (2003) 214 CLR 118; 197 ALR 201; [2003] HCA 22; BC200301915 at [23] and [29]; Branir Pty Ltd v Owston Nominees (No 2) Pty Ltd (2001) 117 FCR 424; [2001] FCA 1833; BC200108132 at [21], [22] and [30] ; Warren v Coombes (1979) 142 CLR 531 at 545; 23 ALR 405; BC7900040 ; Dearman v Dearman (1908) 7 CLR 549 at 557, 560; 15 ALR 287; BC0800010 .

The qualification to the fundamental principle is that an appeal court must recognise both (i) the comparative advantages available to a trial judge as a result of having experienced the whole course of the trial, having heard and observed all of the witnesses and having read all of the other evidence, and (ii) the limitations inherent in even meticulously expressed trial court’s reasons: see Fox v Percy (2003) 214 CLR 118; 197 ALR 201; [2003] HCA 22; BC200301915 at [41] ; Costa v Public Trustee [2008] NSWCA 223; BC200809445 at [76]–[77] . These two considerations impose “natural limitations” on the appeal process and the confidence with which an appeal court can identify error in the first instance decision: Fox v Percy (2003) 214 CLR 118; 197 ALR 201; [2003] HCA 22; BC200301915 at [23] and [26] ; State Rail Authority of New South Wales v Earthline Constructions Pty Ltd (in liq) (1999) 160 ALR 588; [1999] HCA 3; BC9900187 at [72]–[81] and especially at [91] per Kirby J. See further [SCA s 75A.20] .

There is a degree of tension between the basic appeal function and the “natural limitations” on an appeal court’s ability to depart from factual findings in the first instance decision. That tension becomes particularly evident in two situations. The first situation is where the ultimate decision, whilst unaffected by any error of principle, involves a contentious inference, characterisation or assessment – such as the negligence finding in Warren v Coombes (1979) 142 CLR 531; 23 ALR 405; BC7900040 . The second concerns appeals where the contentious factual findings involve assessment of the credibility of witnesses: see State Rail Authority of New South Wales v Earthline Constructions Pty Ltd (in liq) (1999) 160 ALR 588; [1999] HCA 3; BC9900187 at [72]–[81] per Kirby J. In the former situation the resolution of the conflict, and the identification of “error”, may depend on an appeal court’s nuanced characterisation of their disagreement with the original decision as (i) a “preference” as distinct from a “firm preference”, (ii) as relating to a matter that requires a normative conclusion that does not permit subjective choice or discretion, or (iii) one to which effect must be given on appeal because none of the “natural limitations” applies to the first instance decision: see Branir Pty Ltd v Owston Nominees (No 2) Pty Ltd (2001) 117 FCR 424; [2001] FCA 1833; BC200108132 at [24]–[25] and [28] and Costa v The Public Trustee (NSW) [2008] NSWCA 223; BC200809445 at [15]–[19] per Hodgson JA , at [31], [34]–[48] per Ipp JA and at [53], [54] [68]–[97] per Basten JA. The resolution of that tension, in both of the situations referred to, can involve different emphasis on the significance of the “natural limitations”, in the circumstances of individual cases: see Fox v Percy (2003) 214 CLR 118; 197 ALR 201; [2003] HCA 22; BC200301915 at [28], [30]–[31] ; Earthline, above, at [82]; and Branir, above, at [28], [29]; CSR v Della Maddalena (2006) 224 ALR 1; [2006] HCA 1; BC200600188 at [23] and [180] .

The circumstances where an appeal court can, and ought, make different findings of fact or inference are discussed further in [SCA s 75A.15] . The particular relevance of credibility and demeanour to findings challenged in appeal proceedings is discussed further at [SCA s 75A.20] .

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 75A.14] Appeals subject to specific statutory provisions s 75A(4)

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 75A.14] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Administrative Decisions Tribunal Act 1997 ss 119, 120.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 1321.
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 s 142N.
(NSW) Land and Environment Court Act 1979 ss 56A, 57.
(NSW) Mental Health (Forensic Provisions) Act 1990 s 77A.
(NSW) Taxation Administration Act 1996 ss 97, 101.

heading.title: Appeals subject to specific statutory provisions s 75A(4)

p.text: The stipulation that appeals are to be conducted by way of rehearing is subject to the provisions of any other legislation conferring the appeal jurisdiction. A number of statutes provide for an appeal to the Supreme Court from other courts, tribunals and bodies. The precise scope of the appeal in any particular case depends on the terms of the appeal power, and the nature of the issues raised in the appeal. Those matters are extensively discussed in B & L Linings Pty Ltd v Chief Commissioner of State Revenue [2008] NSWCA 187; BC200807313 at [38]–[78] and Thaina Town (on Goulburn) Pty Ltd v City of Sydney Council (2007) 156 LGERA 150; [2007] NSWCA 300; BC200709105 at [92]–[110] . The following summary provides a simplified illustration of the relationship between the present section and some of the more commonly encountered specific appeal provisions.

Administrative Decisions Tribunal Act 1997 ss 119, 120 — appeals on a question of law: SCA s 75A does not operate to expand the scope of the appeal: B & L Linings Pty Ltd v Chief Cmr of State Revenue [2008] NSWCA 187; BC200807313 at [149] ; Golden Harvest (Aust) Pty Ltd v Paing Pty Ltd [2004] NSWCA 85; BC200403313 at [57] .

Corporations Act 2001 (Cth) s 1321 — appeals from decisions of a receiver, administrator or liquidator: SCA s 75A does not itself restrict the nature of the appeal: Re Jay-O-Bees Pty Ltd (in liq) (2004) 50 ACSR 565; [2004] NSWSC 818; BC200406360 at [46]–[49] .

District Court Act 1973 s 142N — residual jurisdiction appeals confined to a question of law: SCA s 75A did not confer power to make findings of fact on appeal: Murray v Cmr of Police (2004) 2 DDCR 31; [2004] NSWCA 365; BC200407664 .

Dust Diseases Tribunal Act s 32 — appeals “in point of law” or involving the admission or rejection of evidence: SCA s 75A does not give power to make findings of fact: Patrick Operations Pty Ltd v Comcare (2006) 68 NSWLR 131; [2006] NSWCA 142; BC200606978 at [39]–[59] per Giles JA and Tobias JA (no power to re-exercise an apportionment discretion on appeal); Seltsam Pty Ltd v Ghaleb (2005) 3 DDCR 1; [2005] NSWCA 2008; BC200506381 at [148]–[166] per Basten JA (the power of the court extended only to the question of law).

Land and Environment Court Act 1979 ss 56A, 57 — appeals on a question of law: SCA s 75A permits exercise of the statutory discretion but not to make any factual findings on which its proper exercise depends: Thaina Town (on Goulburn) Pty Ltd v City of Sydney Council (2007) 156 LGERA 150; [2007] NSWCA 300; BC200709105 at [102]–[110] ; Roads and Traffic Authority v Perry (2001) 52 NSWLR 222; [2001] NSWCA 251; BC200104919 at [63] (no power to make findings of fact); GPT RE Ltd v Belmorgan Property Development Pty Ltd [2008] NSWCA 256; BC200808971 (exercise of discretion by the Council miscarried — appeal allowed — matter remitted to LEC); see Maurici v Chief Cmr of State Revenue (2001) 51 NSWLR 673; [2001] NSWSC 78; BC200103188 for a different approach (cf comments in Thaina Town (on Goulburn) Pty Ltd v City of Sydney Council (2007) 156 LGERA 150; [2007] NSWCA 300; BC200709105 at [92], [151] ).

Mental Health (Forensic Provisions) Act 1990 s 77A — appeals on a question of law or on any other question: SCA s 75A applies to such an appeal, not an appeal hearing de novo: A by his tutor Collins v Mental Health Review Tribunal [2010] NSWSC 1363; BC201008927 at [36]–[50].

Taxation Administration Act 1996 ss 97, 101 — right of review: SCA s 75A does not restrict the nature of the review: Affinity Health Ltd v Chief Cmr of State Revenue (2005) 60 ATR 1; [2005] NSWSC 663; BC200504783 at [54] .

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 75A.15] Drawing inferences and making findings of fact

heading.title: Drawing inferences and making findings of fact

p.text: The basic principle is that, in the exercise of a general appellate jurisdiction, an appeal court should conduct its own independent review of the facts, and give effect to its own conclusions about them: Fox v Percy (2003) 214 CLR 118 at 125–8; 197 ALR 201 at 206–8, 208–9; [2003] HCA 22; BC200301915 at [21]–[25], [27] ; Pledge v Roads and Traffic Authority (2004) 205 ALR 56 at 67–9; 78 ALJR 572; [2004] HCA 13; BC200400863 at [43] ; Anikin v Sierra (2004) 211 ALR 621; 79 ALJR 452; [2004] HCA 64; BC200408400 at [37] and see [SCA s 75A.12] .

The basic principle is qualified by an appeal court’s obligation to give due allowance to the trial judge’s advantages in hearing the case, whether they derive from the oral evidence and demeanour of witnesses or direct observation or the general progress of the hearing (ie, the “dynamics of the trial: NAIS v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (2005) 228 CLR 470; 223 ALR 171; [2005] HCA 77; BC200510689 at [85], [86] . But if, after making due allowance, an appeal court is satisfied that the judgment is affected by an erroneous finding of primary fact, it must give effect to its own conclusion: Fox v Percy (2003) 214 CLR 118; 197 ALR 201; [2003] HCA 22; BC200301915 at [25], [26] and [29] ; CSR Ltd v Maddalena (2006) 224 ALR 1; 80 ALJR 458; [2006] HCA 1; BC200600188 at [16], [22] .

If the judgment under appeal turns on an inference from, or the characterisation of, a primary fact, it is settled that “in general an appellate court is in as good a position as the trial judge to decide on the proper inference to be drawn from facts which are undisputed or which, having been disputed, are the subject of unchallenged findings. In such a case, if the judges of appeal consider … the trial judge was in no better position to decide the particular question than they are themselves, or if, after giving full weight to the decision they consider that it was wrong, they must discharge their duty and give effect to their own judgment”: Warren v Coombes (1979) 142 CLR 531 at 551–2; 23 ALR 405 at 424; 53 ALJR 293; BC7900040 ; see Taylor v Johnson (1983) 151 CLR 422 at 426; 45 ALR 265 at 268; BC8300058 (trial judge expressly disavowed credibility as a basis for his findings); Dawson v Westpac Banking Corp (1991) 104 ALR 295 at 304; 66 ALJR 94; BC9102649 ; Australian Capital Territory v Badcock (2000) 169 ALR 585; [2000] FCA 142; BC200000310 at [37], [48], [51] ; Suvaal v Cessnock City Council (2003) 200 ALR 1; 77 ALJR 1449; [2003] HCA 41; BC200304309 (finding reversed where it was based on inference or surmise rather than witness’ evidence).

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 75A.20] Findings based on credibility

heading.title: Findings based on credibility

p.text: Appellate courts acknowledge that their function is subject to “natural limitations” — because the appeal proceedings are substantially confined to the written record. Those limitations are attributed to the comparative advantages of comprehension and evaluation trial judges derive from their direct perception of the witnesses and the progress of the trial: Fox v Percy (2003) 214 CLR 118; 197 ALR 201; [2003] HCA 22; BC200301915 at [23] ; Rosenberg v Pervical (2001) 205 CLR 434 at 448; 178 ALR 577; [2001] HCA 18; BC200101435 at [41] per McHugh J (“trial by transcript can seldom be an adequate representation of an oral trial”); The SS Hontestroom v The SS Sagaporak [1927] AC 37 at 47 per Lord Sumner (“not to have seen the witnesses puts appellate judges in a permanent position of disadvantage”). Those advantages have particular potential significance where a trial judge’s findings are based on an assessment of witness credibility. For that reason, a trial judge should make specific credibility findings where they are material to the outcome of the proceedings: Government Insurance Office (NSW) v Evans (1990) 21 NSWLR 564 at 577 . But even in the absence of specific credibility findings, if particular factual findings do depend on the judge’s assessment of witness credibility that remains a matter of potential significance on appeal: Abalos v Australian Postal Commission (1990) 171 CLR 167 at 178; 96 ALR 354; [1990] HCA 47; BC9002902 .

The basic proposition is that the “natural limitations” subject appeal courts to a measure of restraint against interfering with findings substantially based on an assessment of witness credibility: Fox v Percy (2003) 214 CLR 118; 197 ALR 201; [2003] HCA 22; BC200301915 . The significance and extent of the restraint required in any particular case is a matter for careful assessment, and should be carried out with a real awareness of the essentially impressionistic and subjective nature of the exercise: see Fox v Percy , above, at [30]–[31]; State Rail Authority v Earthline Constructions Pty Ltd (in liq) (1999) 160 ALR 588 at 616–7; 73 ALJR 306; [1999] HCA 3; BC9900187 and especially Goodrich Aerospace Pty Ltd v Arsic (2006) 66 NSWLR 186; [2006] NSWCA 187; BC200605471 at [16] per Ipp JA.

Nevertheless, appeal courts must make “all due allowance for the advantages available to the trial judge”: Fox v Percy, above, at [29]. They cannot reverse findings based on credibility merely because of their own comparisons and criticisms of the witnesses and their own assessment of the relative probabilities of the case: Paterson v Paterson (1953) 89 CLR 212; [1953] ALR 1095 ; Powell v Streatham Manor Nursing Home [1935] AC 243 at 264; [1935] All ER Rep 58 at 66 ; Benmax v Austin Motor Co Ltd [1955] AC 370; [1955] All ER 326 ; Brunskill v Sovereign Marine & General Insurance Co Ltd (1985) 62 ALR 53; 59 ALJR 842 ; Moran v McMahon (1985) 3 NSWLR 700 at 715 ; Jones v Hyde (1989) 85 ALR 23 at 24; 63 ALJR 349 at 351 . That general principle has been emphasised in various terms in the decided cases. The commonly used expressions are that an appellate court ought not interfere with credibility based findings unless satisfied:

that the trial judge “palpably misused the advantage … of seeing and hearing the witnesses” or that the advantage “could not be sufficient to explain the trial judge's conclusion”: Abalos v Australian Postal Commission (1990) 171 CLR 167 at 178–9; 96 ALR 354 at 362 ; Rosenberg v Pervical (2001) 205 CLR 434 at 447–8; 178 ALR 577 at [37]–[42] , [92] ; Devries v Australian National Railways Commission (1993) 177 CLR 472 at 477, 478–9, 481; 112 ALR 641 at 645–9 ; Zuvela v Cosmarnan Concrete Pty Ltd (1996) 140 ALR 227; 71 ALJR 29 ; (note however Kirby J’s criticism of the ambiguity of this expression in SRA v Earthline Constructions Pty Ltd (1999) 160 ALR 588 at [77] ); or

that the findings are inconsistent with, or glaringly improbable having regard to, incontrovertible evidence: Fox v Percy, above, at [30], [31]; Agbaba v Witter (1977) 14 ALR 187 at 195; 51 ALJR 503 at 508 per Jacobs J; State Rail Authority of New South Wales v Earthline Constructions Pty Ltd (in liq) (1999) 160 ALR 588; 73 ALJR 306; [1999] HCA 3 at [72] [81] .

Despite the restraint these various expressions require, they also explicitly recognise that a trial judge's findings of fact are not immune from appeal merely because they are based on an assessment of the credibility of witnesses. In fact no "short formula" restricts the situations in which that kind of appellate review is permissible: State Rail Authority of New South Wales v Earthline Constructions Pty Ltd (in liq) (1999) 160 ALR 588; 73 ALJR 306; [1999] HCA 3 citing Devries v Australian National Railways Commission (1993) 177 CLR 472 at 480; 112 ALR 641 at 646–7 ; Damberg v Damberg (2001) 52 NSWLR 492; [2001] NSWCA 87; BC200102714 at [89] per Heydon JA.

An appellate court is both free, and obliged, to evaluate a witness's testimony against independently established facts. Where such a comparison is available there is no justification for merely deferring to the trial judge's credibility assessment: Soc d'Advances Commerciales v Merchants Marine Insurance Co [1924] 20 Ll L Rep 140 at 152 ; Lek v Mathews (1927) 29 Ll L Rep 141; Re F (a minor) [1976] Fam 238 at 259 . On the contrary, the comparison may require reversal of the trial judge's findings: Voulis v Kozary (1975) 180 CLR 177; 7 ALR 126 ; Chambers v Jobling (1986) 7 NSWLR 1; 4 MVR 363 (comparison between witnesses' evidence at trial and a prior statement); State Rail Authority of New South Wales v Earthline Constructions Pty Ltd (in liq) (1999) 160 ALR 588; 73 ALJR 306; [1999] HCA 3 (improper rejection of a witness whose testimony was corroborated by unchallenged oral evidence); Fox v Percy (2003) 214 CLR 118; 197 ALR 201; [2003] HCA 22; BC200301915 (credibility findings unjustified in the light of unexplained objective evidence); Goodrich Aerospace Pty Ltd v Arsic (2006) 66 NSWLR 186; [2006] NSWCA 187; BC200605471 at [16] per Ipp JA (failure to adequately address material evidence); King v Collins [2007] NSWCA 122; BC200703977 (factual errors in reasoning of the trial judge were sufficiently material to outweigh credibility findings).

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 75A.25] Findings based on matters of impression

heading.title: Findings based on matters of impression

p.text: In some instances the trial judge's findings of fact are based on observation of physical objects or involve a qualitative assessment of particular features of the evidence. Where the findings involve matters of impression of this kind an appeal court is obliged to pay particular respect to the finding unless it is satisfied that it is clearly wrong: SW Hart & Co Pty Ltd v Edwards Hot Water Systems (1985) 159 CLR 466 at 478; 61 ALR 251 ; Federal Cmr of Taxation v Chubb Australia Ltd (1995) 56 FCR 557; 128 ALR 489 at 491 ; S & I Publishing Pty Ltd v Australian Surf Life Saver Pty Ltd (1998) 88 FCR 354; 168 ALR 396 at 400 .

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 75A.27] Findings based on photographic evidence

heading.title: Findings based on photographic evidence

p.text: There is a degree of imprecision about the extent to which a court may base contentious findings on the interpretation of photographic evidence. Some authorities have taken the view that a court cannot base contentious findings on its own interpretation of photographic evidence: see Schmidt v Schmidt [1969] QWN 3 ; Short v Barrett [1990] NSWCA 164; BC9003193. The better view is that there are situations where photographs can be regarded as primary evidence – provided the court is satisfied of the accuracy of the photographic reproduction and the evidence relating to it: R v Ames [1964-5] NSWR 1489 at 1491 ; Yarrabee Coal Company Ltd v Lujans (2009) 53 MVR 1873; [2009] NSWCA 85; BC200906516 at [10]–[19], at [179] , per Giles JA, at [20]–[28] per Beazley JA. However judicial interpretation of photographic evidence cannot be used as a substitute for apparently credible testimonial evidence or as providing a basis for rejecting otherwise persuasive testimonial evidence: Angel v Hawkesbury City Council (2008) Aust Torts Reports ¶81-955; [2008] NSWCA 130; BC200804860 at [68]–[72] per Beazley and Tobias JA; Blacktown City Council v Hocking [2008] NSWCA 144; BC200804863 at [7]–[13] per Spigelman CJ and at [167]–[171] per Tobias JA.

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 75A.30] Findings based on acceptance of expert evidence

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 75A.30] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 79.

heading.title: Findings based on acceptance of expert evidence

p.text: The basic criterion for the admissibility of expert evidence is the application of specialised knowledge to a particular factual situation: see s 79 of the Evidence Act 1995. Consequently the force and reliability of expert evidence is generally amenable to a degree of rational exposition and evaluation. The absence of challenge to an expert’s opinion may provide a proper basis for accepting their evidence: M & EM Hull Pty Ltd v Thompson [2001] NSWCA 359; BC200106420 per Rolfe AJA at [21]. But the court is not bound to accept any evidence, including expert evidence, merely because it is uncontradicted: see [29.5.110].

Where there is conflicting expert evidence, the court must express a reasoned basis for discriminating between the conflicting opinions: Taupau v HVAC Constructions (Qld) Pty Ltd [2012] NSWCA 293; BC201207362 at [130]–[134] . In particular, it is not sufficient for the judge merely to record a general subjective preference for the evidence of a particular witness: Moylan v Nutrasweet Co (the Copper Seven case) [2000] NSWCA 337; BC200007222 ; Wiki v Atlantis Relocations (NSW) Pty Ltd (2004) 60 NSWLR 127; 1 DDCR 554; [2004] NSWCA 174; BC200403676 (preference given to an expert witness described as “more eminent”); Flannery v Halifax Estate Agencies Ltd [2000] 1 All ER 373; (1999) 149 NLJ 284; [2000] 1 WLR 377; [1999] BLR 107 .

Credibility of expert witnesses will rarely be in issue in proceedings. Nevertheless, findings about matters that were the subject of expert evidence may be influenced by the judge's assessment of the expert witness in the manner in which the evidence is given: Public Trustee v Commonwealth BC9506816 per Mahoney JA. Appellate courts are required to give proper weight to the advantage that the trial judge derives from having seen and heard the evidence being given at the trial: Ahmedi v Ahmedi (1991) 23 NSWLR 288 ; Wilsher v Essex Area Health Authority [1988] AC 1074; [1988] 1 All ER 871; [1988] 2 WLR 557 ; Chambers v Jobling (1986) 7 NSWLR 1; 4 MVR 363 .

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 75A.35] Appeals involving challenges to the exercise of judicial discretion — other than matters of practice and procedure (as to which see [SCA s 101.60])

heading.title: Appeals involving challenges to the exercise of judicial discretion — other than matters of practice and procedure (as to which see [SCA s 101.60] )

p.text: The concept of a judicial discretion generally conveys a decision making process in which no specific consideration(s) are necessarily determinative of the orders to be made in the disposition of the proceedings. But within that general conception judicial discretions may vary between, on the one hand, those which are restrained only by their subject matter and purpose and, on the other, those where a particular opinion or satisfaction is a threshold requirement for a particular outcome: Coal and Allied Operations Pty Ltd v Australian Industrial Relations Commission [2000] HCA 47 at [26] . Various alternative criteria have been stated as expressing the onus on an appellant who challenges the first instance exercise of the discretion: Ainsworth v Burden [2005] NSWCA 174; BC200504199 at [52] (presumption in favour of the correctness of the decision). Such an appellant must affirmatively satisfy the court that there has been a wrongful exercise of the discretion, either because:
the trial judge acted on an incorrect principle of law;
the judge failed to take into account relevant considerations;
the judge made some relevant error of fact; or
the judge reached a result that is plainly unreasonable or unjust.

This principle has been applied in a wide range of appeals from decisions involving the exercise of judicial discretionary powers: Dinsdale v R (2000) 202 CLR 321; 175 ALR 315; [2000] HCA 54; BC200006053 at [3] (sentence); House v R (1936) 55 CLR 499 at 504–5; 10 ALJR 202; BC3690121 (sentence); R v Carroll (2002) 213 CLR 635; 194 ALR 1; [2002] HCA 55; BC200207276 (stay of proceedings); Gronow v Gronow (1979) 144 CLR 513; 29 ALR 129 (custody); Lovell v Lovell (1950) 81 CLR 513; [1950] ALR 944 (custody); Klein v Domus Pty Ltd (1963) 109 CLR 467; [1964] ALR 492 (extension of time); Leeder v Ellis [1953] AC 52 (refusal to permit fresh evidence on appeal); Mace v Murray (1955) 92 CLR 370; 28 ALJR 642 (adoption); House v R (1936) 55 CLR 499 at 504–5; 10 ALJR 202 (sentence); Charles Osenton & Co v Johnston [1942] AC 130; [1941] 2 All ER 245 (referral to referee); Londish v Gulf Pacific Pty Ltd (1993) 45 FCR 128; 117 ALR 361 (amendment at end of trial). The same general approach applies to appeals against the assessment of damages by a judge: Gamser v Nominal Defendant (1977) 136 CLR 145; 13 ALR 387; 51 ALJR 315; BC7700032 ; Wilson v Peisley (1975) 7 ALR 571; 50 ALJR 207; BC7500066 ; Miller v Jennings (1954) 92 CLR 190; [1954] ALR 1103 29 ALJR 43; BC5400690 ; Wilkes v Bradford Kendall Ltd [1962] NSWR 1303; (1962) 79 WN (NSW) 850 at 853 ; Moran v McMahon (1985) 3 NSWLR 700 at 716–21; (1985) Aust Torts Reports 80-762; (1986) NSWJB 25 .

Where the appellant establishes that the trial judge's decision involves injustice to it, the wrongful exercise of the discretionary power, the appeal court is obliged to review the order made: Maxwell v Keun [1928] 1 KB 645 at 653; [1927] All ER Rep 335 at 338–9 ; Collier-Garland (Properties) Pty Ltd v Northern Transport Co Pty Ltd (1964) 82 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 125 at 127 ; Bloch v Bloch (1981) 180 CLR 390 at 395–6; 37 ALR 55 at 58–9; 55 ALJR 701 ; Walker v Walker [1967] 1 All ER 412 at 415; [1967] 1 WLR 327 .

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 75A.40] Appeals involving challenges to “evaluative” characterisations and findings

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 75A.40] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Succession Act 2006 Succession Act 2006.

heading.title: Appeals involving challenges to “evaluative” characterisations and findings

p.text: In proceedings where legislation provides specific statutory criteria for the exercise of particular powers, the nature of those criteria, and in particular the extent to which they refer to considerations amenable to objective and precise evaluation, will influence the proper approach to appellate review of relevant findings: see Perpetual Trustee Co Ltd v Khoshaba (2005) 14 BPR 26,639; [2006] NSWCA 41; BC200602108 at [108]–[111] ; DAO v R (2011) 278 ALR 765; [2011] NSWCCA 63; BC201102128 at [20]–[52] and [83]–[96].

Where the case involves the application of a statutory formula which requires a judge to form an opinion, for example as to whether conduct is “fair” or “reasonable” or “unconscionable” or "misleading", or as to whether evidence has “significant probative value”, it is unclear whether it will always be correct to categorise the trial judge's decision as one involving the exercise of a discretion: George Mitchell (Chesterhall) Ltd v Finney Lock Seeds Ltd [1963] Com LR 209; [1983] 2 AC 803; [1983] 2 All ER 737; [1983] 3 WLR 163 ; cf Antonovic v Volker (1986) 7 NSWLR 151; [1987] ANZ ConvR 425; (1987) NSW ConvR 55-332 ; Beneficial Finance Corp Ltd v Karavas (1991) 23 NSWLR 256 at 259, 263, 281; [1992] ANZ ConvR 462; (1991) ASC 56-062; (1991) Aust Contract R 90-001 ; Attorney-General (NSW) v X (2000) 49 NSWLR 653; [2000] NSWCA 199; BC200004289 at [33], [45]–[55] per Spigelman CJ to the same effect Mobilo v Balliotis [1998] 3 VLR 833 at 835, 838 and 853; BC9706067 . The essential uncertainty is as to whether the criterion is one of “degree and evaluation” or alternatively, one of logical assessment in the application of a legal standard: DAO v R (2011) 278 ALR 765; [2011] NSWCCA 63; BC201102128 at [87] .

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 75A.45] Additional evidence on appeal — “fresh” evidence and “further” evidence

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 75A.45] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 SCA ss 75A(8)–(10).

heading.title: Additional evidence on appeal — “fresh” evidence and “further” evidence

p.text: The Court of Appeal may receive additional evidence on the hearing of an appeal. Different principles apply depending upon whether the additional evidence relates to matters that occurred before, but were not adduced as evidence in, the trial (“further evidence”), and to matters that occurred after the trial (“fresh evidence”): SCA ss 75A(8)–(10) .

If the evidence relates to matters that occurred after the trial there is no requirement to show special grounds to justify the reception of the evidence: CDJ v VAJ (No 1) (1998) 197 CLR 172; 157 ALR 686; [1998] HCA 67; BC9805442 at [54], [97] and [102] ; and see [51.51.15] where the matter is considered in more detail.

If the appeal is from a judgment given after “a hearing on the merits” then “special grounds” must exist to justify the reception of further evidence: SCA s 75A(8) . (Subject to any contrary provision where the right of appeal arises under a different statutory provision.)

The general, but not inflexible, position is that in order to satisfy the “special grounds” requirement the proffered “further evidence” must satisfy the three requirements of: (i) pre-trial unavailability; (ii) credibility; and (iii) highly probative: Akins v National Australia Bank (1994) 34 NSWLR 155 at 160; [1995] ANZ ConvR 67; (1994) ASC 56-279; BC9403049 ; see further [51.51.5]–[51.51.10] where the relevant principles are considered in more detail. This general position emphasises the potential importance of the three criteria, but does not make the presence or absence of any single criterion necessarily determinative: Phoenix Commercial Enterprises Pty Ltd v City of Canada Bay Council [2010] NSWCA 64; BC201001880 esp at [13]–[22] per Spigelman CJ and [135]–[136] per Campbell JA; Tijong v Tijong [2012] NSWCA 201; BC201204951 at [168] ff (application to adduce further evidence refused — no “insistent” interest of justice; evidence available for use at original hearing); Hammond v JP Morgan Trust Australia Ltd (2012) 16 BPR 30,901; [2012] NSWCA 295; BC201207363 at [5], [24] (rightly conceded by the respondent that “special grounds” existed justifying the receipt of further evidence, notwithstanding that the evidence was available at the time of hearing — evidence not led at hearing because appellant was not present or represented).

However, “special grounds” may exist even in circumstances where the three requirements recognised in the Akins case have not been satisfied: Nowlan v Marson Transport Pty Ltd (2001) 53 NSWLR 116; 34 MVR 495; [2001] NSWCA 346; BC200105900 at [14] (further medical evidence admitted in relation to an unanticipated defence); Malone v New South Wales National Parks and Wildlife Service [2001] NSWCA 345; BC200105899 (medical evidence admitted where matter thought not to have been contested in the proceedings below); Aztech Science Pty Ltd v Atlanta Aerospace (Woy Woy) Pty Ltd (2005) 55 ACSR 1; 23 ACLC 1903; [2005] NSWCA 319; BC200506977 at [102], [107] (short confirmatory documents alluded to in the existing evidence).

Furthermore, the decision as to what constitutes “special grounds” may be influenced by the nature of the decision under appeal, and the extent to which it can properly be characterised as a “hearing on the merits”. Some decisions, despite being made after contested hearings, are essentially interlocutory in nature and in the case of such an appeal its very nature may justify the receipt of further evidence without the need to demonstrate the existence of other special grounds: Wickstead v Browne (1992) 30 NSWLR 1; [1992] NSWCA 272; BC9203970 . As to what constitutes a “hearing on the merits” see [s 75A.50] .

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 75A.50] Judgment after a trial or hearing on the merits

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 75A.50] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 50.1.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 75A(7)–(9).

heading.title: Judgment after a trial or hearing on the merits

p.text: In any appeal to which r 50.1 applies, and in any appeal in the Supreme Court (see SCA s 75A(7)–(9) ), “special grounds” are required to receive “further” evidence if the appeal is from a “judgment after a trial or hearing on the merits”. This expression is amenable to illustration by examples at opposite ends of the range of potentially applicable circumstances.

At one end of the range, a judgment or hearing is “on the merits” if it involves the binding final determination of issues of fact or law that resolve the proceedings: Bridie v Messina (1965) 66 SR (NSW) 446; [1965] NSWR 332 ; typically after a “real” trial involving a thorough examination of the evidence: Reed v Nutt (1890) 24 QBD 669 at 673, 674 ; Ellis v Burton [1975] 1 WLR 386 at 389; [1975] 1 All ER 395 at 398 . See also R v Hay; Ex parte Patane [1981] Qd R 152 .

At the other end of the range of possibly relevant circumstances, the expression “hearing on the merits” does not include determinations based on discontinuance, dismissal (for want of prosecution, absence of cause of action or procedural non-compliance), absence of power or irregularity: Nadilo v Director of Public Prosecutions (1995) 35 NSWLR 738 at 742 and 745 (interlocutory ruling on admissibility).

Between these two illustrative examples fall a range of circumstances in which courts may deliver judgments, after contested hearings, that have the practical effect of determining the parties’ respective entitlements but which are nevertheless classified as interlocutory judgments or orders: for examples of which see [SCA s 101.82] . Whether judgments of this type should be classified as having been made after “a trial or hearing on the merits” is the subject of judicial debate. In Martin v Abbott Australasia Pty Ltd [1981] 2 NSWLR 430 at 434–6 Hunt J expressed the view that any judgment after a contested interlocutory hearing should be regarded as having been made “after a hearing on the merits”. That view was accepted by Yeldham J in Baker v Australian Asbestos Insulations Pty Ltd [1984] 3 NSWLR 595 at 600–1 and by the Queensland Full Court in Clarke v Japan Machines (Aust) Pty Ltd [1984] 1 Qd R 404 at 408. But it is inconsistent with Wickstead v Browne (1992) 30 NSWLR 1 at 11 , and was doubted by Bryson J in Hartigan v International Krishna Consciousness [1999] NSWSC 139; BC9807519 (an appeal against dismissal for want of prosecution) and was criticised, on the basis that it involved an impermissible interpolation in the statutory wording, by Heydon JA in Nominal Defendant v Manning (2000) 50 NSWLR 139; 31 MVR 524; [2000] NSWCA 80; BC200005011 at [56]–[66] .

The resolution of this debate probably lies in accepting the validity of the broad general distinction illustrated by the examples given earlier in this note, and a consequential recognition that the interlocutory character of the judgment in question is, of itself, an unreliable basis for proper characterisation of the nature of the hearing in question. Instead, it is necessary to consider the particular issues involved and the ultimate effect of the judgment itself: Romeo v Papalia [2012] NSWCA 221; BC201205506 at [78], [86] .

On this approach, proper characterisation of the particular hearing will be determined partly by precedent and partly by analogy. So far as precedent is concerned the following judgments have been regarded as made after hearings on the merits:

a judgment granting a plaintiff’s application for summary judgment (Langdale v Danby [1982] 1 WLR 1123; [1982] 3 All ER 129 ; Sunbird Plaza Pty Ltd v Aurisch Investments Pty Ltd (No 2) [1983] 2 Qd R 383 );
a judgment refusing to set aside a consent judgment: Romeo v Papalia [2012] NSWCA 221; BC201205506 at [78], [86] ;
a judgment granting an interlocutory injunction (though the point was not argued): (Clarke v Japan Machines (Aust) Pty Ltd , above;
a judgment refusing to set aside a statutory demand); Australia Freyssinet Pty Ltd v Marlin International Pty Ltd [2002] NSWSC 892; BC20020569 .
By way of contrast, the following judgments have been regarded as not involving a hearing on the merits:
a judgment granting a defendant’s application for summary dismissal Wickstead v Browne , above, at 11;
a judgment dismissing proceedings for want of prosecution: Hartigan v International Krishna Consciousness , above;
a judgment striking out part of a claim as an abuse of process: Clark v NSW [2012] NSWCA 139; BC201203424 at [59] ;
a judgment refusing an application for extension of time Nominal Defendant v Manning , above at [56]–[66] per Heydon JA;
a judgment refusing a stay of execution: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v Sakovitas [2010] NSWSC 1322; BC201008934 .

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 75A.52] Additional evidence on appeals from interlocutory judgments

heading.title: Additional evidence on appeals from interlocutory judgments

p.text: There is some controversy, fuelled by the differing views about the expression “judgment after a trial or hearing on the merits”, as to whether special grounds are required to justify the admission of further evidence on an appeal against an interlocutory order. The better view is the “hearing on the merits” criterion depends on the substantive nature of the proceedings, rather than the mere classification of the particular order as either “interlocutory: or “final”: Romeo v Papalia [2012] NSWCA 221; BC201205506 at [78] . Whether or not special grounds are strictly required, it seems to be accepted that a more liberal interpretation can properly be given to the need for special grounds in appeals from an interlocutory hearing and especially in matters of practice and procedure: Martin v Abbott Australasia Pty Ltd [1981] 2 NSWLR 430 at 436–7 ; Nominal Defendant v Manning (2000) 50 NSWLR 139; 31 MVR 524; [2000] NSWCA 80; BC200005011 at [60]–[67].

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 75A.55] Any order the nature of the case requires

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 75A.55] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 75A, s 75A(4), s 75A(7), 75A(8).
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 51.52, 51.53, 51.54.

heading.title: Any order the nature of the case requires

p.text: Where the present section applies, without the restriction contemplated by SCA s 75A(4) , the court may make any order that could have been made by the court below. The court may also admit further evidence on appeal, under SCA s 75A(7) and 75A(8) . Specific additional powers are to be found in UCPR rr 51.52 , 51.53 and 51.54 , and the court exercising appellate jurisdiction has a general power to make any orders the interests of justice require.

Where the nature or scope of the appeal is subject to particular restrictions or enlargement, the scope of the appeal orders will depend on the particular appeal jurisdiction, and the reconciliation of those provisions with the terms of SCA s 75A — see [SCA s 75A.12] . Even in those instances, if a particular outcome is mandated by the determination of the appeal issues, the court may make an order disposing of the proceedings: Scicluna v NSW Land and Housing Corp [2008] NSWCA 277; BC200809570 at [25] and [33] per Basten JA citing Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs v Guo (1997) 191 CLR 559 at 579, 598–600; 144 ALR 567; [1997] HCA 22; BC9702433 ; Chen Shi Hai v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (2000) 201 CLR 293; 170 ALR 553; [2000] HCA 19; BC200001745 at [41]–[42] and [82] .

Where the appeal is from a trial by jury (to which SCA ss 102–108 apply), and even in some circumstances involving appeals by way of rehearing, proper exercise of the appeal jurisdiction may require the proceedings to be remitted for further hearing at first instance. The nature of the restrictions that may be imposed in relation to orders of that type are discussed in [51.53.16] .
As to the court’s powers in relation to the consensual disposition of an appeal see [36.1A.10] .

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 75A.56] Changes in the law after judgment

heading.title: Changes in the law after judgment

p.text: It may in certain circumstances be appropriate to consider changes in the law which occur between the date of trial and the hearing of the appeal: Attorney-General v Vernazza [1960] 3 All ER 97; [1960] AC 965 ; Re Chennell (1878) 8 Ch D 492 at 505; Quilter v Mapleson (1882) 9 QBD 672 at 676; New Brunswick Railway Co v British and French Trust Corp [1939] AC 1 at 32–3 ; Re Dempsey; Ex parte Currie (1968) 70 SR (NSW) 1 ; Attorney-General v Birmingham Tame and Rea District Drainage Board [1912] AC 788 ; Traecey v Churchill [1980] 1 NSWLR 442; Luther v Sagor [1921] 3 KB 532; Haile Selassie v Cable & Wireless Ltd (No 2) [1939] Ch 182 (retrospective diplomatic recognition); compare Norwest Refrigeration Services Pty Ltd v Bain Dawes (WA) Pty Ltd (1984) 157 CLR 149; 55 ALR 509 at 525 and Wilson v Liverpool City Council [1971] 1 All ER 628; [1971] 1 WLR 302 (subsequent favourable decision by the House of Lords). Although it is not appropriate to deprive a party of the benefit of the result of the hearing below by applying subsequent legislation which has no retrospective element: Re A Debtor [1936] 1 Ch 237; see also [51.16.5] and [51.53.105]–[51.53.130] which deal generally with the ability to raise on appeal matters that were not relied upon at the trial.

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 75A.57] Repayment of judgment after successful appeal

heading.title: Repayment of judgment after successful appeal

p.text: If a judgment is set aside on appeal the court will order restitution of any moneys paid under the judgment set aside: TCN Channel 9 Pty Ltd v Antoniadis (No 2) (1999) 48 NSWLR 381; [1999] NSWCA 104; BC9901834 (repayment where re-trial ordered on appeal). The entitlement to a restitutionary order for repayment is a matter of right, rather than judicial discretion: Woolworths Ltd v Strong (No 2) (2011) 80 NSWLR 445; [2011] NSWCA 72; BC201102952 at [25] ; Wardle v Agricultural and Rural Finance Pty Ltd [2012] NSWCA 388; BC201210610 at [103]ff (orders should not be made conditional on the result of a re-hearing). The order should include provision for repayment with interest: Commonwealth v McCormack (1984) 155 CLR 273 at 276; 55 ALR 185; 58 ALJR 53; BC8400476 ; Commissioner for Railways (NSW) v Cavanough (1935) 53 CLR 220 at 225; [1935] ALR 304; (1935) 9 ALJR 116b; BC3500031 ; Government Insurance Office (NSW) v Healy (No 2) (1991) 22 NSWLR 380; BC9102212 (repayment of excess); Heydon v NRMA Ltd (No 2) (2001) 53 NSWLR 600; [2001] NSWCA 445; BC200108069 (repayment should normally be at the pre-judgment interest rate); Cox v Hakes (1890) 15 App Cas 506 at 547; 54 JP 820; 60 LJQB 89; 63 LT 392 ; Rodger v Comptoir d'Escompte de Paris (1871) LR3PC 465; 17 ER 120 ; Merchant Banking Co v Maud (1874) LR18Eq 659 ; Heavener v Loomes (1924) 34 CLR 306 at 323; 30 ALR 263; BC2400027 ; see also Edge v Gallon [1899] WN 137 and Ashworth v English Card Clothing Co Ltd (No 2) [1904] 1 Ch 704 , which deal with orders for the repayment of costs received by the respondent's solicitors. Where the appeal results in a money judgment in favour of the appellant the court may order interest from the date of the judgment at first instance: Nichol v Allyacht Spars Pty Ltd (No 2) (1988) 165 CLR 306; 81 ALR 272; 62 ALJR 557; BC8802664 . Any orders for restitution should be sought on the hearing of the appeal: see further [51.54.5] and [51.19.5] .

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 75A.58] Supervisory jurisdiction — orders for repayment

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 75A.58] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 69.

heading.title: Supervisory jurisdiction — orders for repayment

p.text: The same principle that requires the court to make orders for restitution in appellate proceedings also applies where the court exercises supervisory jurisdiction over inferior courts and tribunals. If a defendant succeeds in having a determination quashed, in the exercise of the supervisory powers conferred by s 69 , the court may order restitution not only of payments made by him or her (including fines) but also in respect of benefits that may have been enjoyed by the other party: Production Spray Painting & Panel Beating Pty Ltd v Newnham (No 2) (1992) 27 NSWLR 659 (orders of the Industrial Tribunal); R v Jones (1722) 1 Str 474; 93 ER 643; R v Wilson (1835) 3 Ad & E 817; 111 ER 624 at 631; R v Hellier (1851) 17 QB 229; 117 ER 1267 at 1270 .

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 75A.60] Orders affecting persons not parties to the appeal

heading.title: Orders affecting persons not parties to the appeal

p.text: In appropriate circumstances the court has power to alter a judgment even in favour of a party who has not appealed: Attorney-General v Simpson [1901] 2 Ch 671; Rutherford v Richardson [1922] P 144; [1923] AC 1 (successful appeal by intervenor challenging findings of adultery, decree of dissolution set aside); Hanson v Wearmouth Coal Co Ltd [1939] 3 All ER 47 (unsuccessful appeal by a co-defendant but order for contribution made against other defendants against whom the plaintiff had failed at the trial); Re Whiston [1924] 1 Ch 122; Helicopter Sales (Aust) Pty Ltd v Rotor-Work Pty Ltd (1974) 132 CLR 1; 4 ALR 77 . As to the right of non-parties to lodge an appeal see [SCA s 101.10] .

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 75A.65] Appeals to the High Court of Australia

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 75A.65] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.

heading.title: Appeals to the High Court of Australia

p.text: Appeals can be made from the court to the High Court of Australia. Sections 35 and 35A of the Judiciary Act 1903 provide the basis for such appeals: see [335,050] and [335,055] behind guide card “Other Legislation” in Vol 3.

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 75A.70] Discretionary judgment — valuation appeals

heading.title: Discretionary judgment — valuation appeals

p.text: With a valuation appeal, because the assessment of value involves the exercise of a discretionary judgment, an appellate court should not substitute its opinion for that of the court below unless it is shown that the court acted on a wrong principle of law or the valuation was erroneous: Commonwealth v Reeve (1949) 78 CLR 410 at 423 ; Emerald Quarry Industries Pty Ltd v Cmr of Highways (1979) 142 CLR 351 at 356, 374; 24 ALR 37 at 41, 56 ; Federal Cmr of Taxation v St Helen's Farm (ACT) Pty Ltd (1981) 146 CLR 336 at 381; 34 ALR 23 at 51 and Valuer-General v Fenton Nominees Pty Ltd (1982) 150 CLR 160 at 164; 42 ALR 371 at 373 .

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 75A.75] Disagreement as to the order to be made

heading.title: Disagreement as to the order to be made

p.text: Where there is no majority view as to the order to be made see [SCA s 45.5] .

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 75A.80] Amendment or recall of final judgment

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 75A.80] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 36.16.

heading.title: Amendment or recall of final judgment

p.text: The court can recall judgments and orders before they have been formally entered: see UCPR r 36.16 and [36.16.45] , [36.16.50] . As to the setting aside or variation after entry see [36.16.52] and [36.16.53] . There is a limited power to consider matters that occur after judgment: see [36.16.80] .

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 75A.85] Appeal from a specified tribunal

heading.title: Appeal from a specified tribunal

p.text: Normally the court will only hear appeals from final decisions of another court or tribunal and this is so whether there is a general right of appeal or one limited to questions of law only: Bromley v Housing Commission of New South Wales (1985) 3 NSWLR 407 distinguished Metropolitan Water Sewerage and Drainage Board v Histon [1982] 2 NSWLR 720; unless, perhaps, the decision sought to be appealed from can be regarded as in substance a final decision on a separate or independent part of the case: Blue Mountains City Council v Hudson (1985) 56 LGRA 360 ; Director-General, Social Services v Chaney (1980) 47 FLR 80; 31 ALR 571 . However, in any particular case the jurisdiction of the court to hear the appeal ultimately depends on the proper construction of the statute in question: eg, De Pater v CSR Chemicals Ltd [1981] 2 NSWLR 760.
[s 76 rep Act No 28 of 2005, effective 15 August 2005]
